Posts.Content: disclaimer: taking the advice of someone you have never met and who has never examined you, based on a conversation on a message board, is probably not a good way to manage your health. :-) So take what I say with a grain of salt (ie don't put a lot of faith in it). See what your doctor thinks, and the two of you should make a plan. Dear Tylette, There is something going on because you have a rash that comes and goes. Is there anything you can think of that happens to that breast that does not happen to the other breast? Does your husband favor that breast during lovemaking? Does he brush his teeth beforehand? If it is cancer, it will get bigger and you may eventually be able to feel a small knot. Perhaps one course of action would be for you to check for a mass there once a week in the shower when soapy, and for an ultrasound to be done every 3 months even if no mass is found (ultrasounds are harmless as they do not involve ionizing radiation like mammograms). If nothing turns up over the course of the next year, the ultrasounds could stop. I would still get mammograms according to the usual schedule (annually if you are over the age of 40). This is just my suggestion. If your doctor has a different suggestion, I would strongly advise you to pay no attention to me and to decide for yourself based on what the two of you talk about. If other rashes start to appear elsewhere, a good next step would be to change laundry detergents and change soaps and see a dermatologist. Is there any history of eczema or psoriasis in the family? Best of Luck to you, -Amnia
Posts.Title: Paget's Disease

Posts.Content: Dear Tylette, if it continues to recur it should be biopsied. breast cancer is readily curable with a lumpectomy in the very early stages, and much harder to treat once it has a chance to spread. -Amnia ------------------------ PAGET'S DISEASE OF THE BREAST Paget’s disease of the breast is an eczema-like change in the skin of the nipple, and 9 out of 10 women who have this have an underlying breast cancer. The underlying breast cancer may be an invasive breast cancer or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). In DCIS, the cancer cells are completely contained within the milk ducts. Around half of the women who have Paget’s disease will have a breast lump that can be felt at the time it is diagnosed. Paget’s disease occurs in about 1–2 out of every 100 women with breast cancer. It usually occurs in women in their 50s, but can occur at an earlier or later age. It can affect men but this is extremely rare. It usually first appears as a scaly, red rash affecting the nipple and sometimes the dark area of skin surrounding the nipple (the areola). The rash always affects the nipple first, and may then affect the areola. It does not go away and may become sore. The area may bleed slightly. ------------------------ read the rest of the article at: http://www.cancerbackup.org.uk/Cancertype/Breast/Typesofbreastcancer/Pagetsdisease

Posts.Content: this is absolutely your choice to make. a lot of people make the choice not to take the drug. yackiejay is one of them in this very forum. make the decision an informed decision. understand what went into your being offered the drug before you refuse it. they took a lot of people with exactly your disease who had exactly the same treatment you had and they divided them into two groups. they gave one group the drug and gave the other group nothing. they started adding up cancer recurrences and adding up side effects. the results showed the group that received the drug did far better in terms of less cancer, and that the side effects were quite tolerable and worth it (since there was so much less cancer). this process is called a clinical trial. to look at lists of clinical trials, explore clinicaltrial.gov there are many drugs that fail clinical trials and once the trial is over they are never offered to anyone ever again. you would not have been offered this drug if it did not have a favorable risk/benefit ratio in its clinical trial. imagine how you would feel if you refuse the drug, and in 6 months you find a lump. you would be kicking yourself. in fact, this is the situation a couple notes down in this forum. Margarita did not faithfully take her arimidex, and here is what she said: Quote: Margarita said: "[I was] Just Diagnosed With Mets to Bone/lung..I'm kicking myself for not staying on it [arimidex] more faithfully." http://www.cancercompass.com/message-board/message/single,7593,1.htm They say the mark of a smart person is they can learn from their mistakes; the mark of a genius is they can learn from other people's mistakes. it is up to you if you want to be a smart person or a genius. it is your body and the decision is yours, as well as living with the consequences of that decision. either way, best of luck, i hope you never have to hear a doctor utter the word cancer ever again :-) , -Amnia
Posts.Title: Refusing Arimidex

Posts.Content: No, Anastrozole (Arimidex®) and Exemestane (Aromasin®) are not the same drug, but they are both in the same class. Aromatase inhibitors are drugs used in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Aromatase inhibitors work by inhibiting aromatase, an enzyme which converts androgens into estrogens. Breast tissue is stimulated by estrogens; decreasing estrogen prevents cancer recurrence. In contrast to pre-menopausal women, in whom most of the estrogen is produced in the ovaries, in post-menopausal women most of the body's estrogen is produced in the adrenal gland from the conversion of androgens. THIS IS WHY TERRBEAR ABOVE WAS NOT SAFE EVEN THOUGH SHE HAD A "TOTAL" HYSTERECTOMY ("total" means includes ovaries). In the past, tamoxifen had been the standard treatment. Now, the best treatment is an AI for postmenopausal estrogen receptor positive breast cancers. The aromatase inhibitors: * Aminoglutethimide * Anastrozole (Arimidex®) * Letrozole (Femara®) * Exemestane (Aromasin®) * Formestane (Lentaron®)

Posts.Content: Q: "If I do the radiation only and use natural progestrone (sic) cream, balanced nutrition and exercise as a means of trying to stay cancer free, is that just wishful thinking?" A: Yes, that is just wishful thinking. Although most women do not get any side effects from tamoxifen, it is possible that you might. But you should not only think about what may happen if you DO take the tamoxifen, you should also think about what may happen if you DON'T take the tamoxifen. In medicine, there is a concept called the risk/benefit ratio. There is risk to taking tamoxifen, but it is very small compared to the risk of more ductal cancer. Here are the facts: the addition of tamoxifen to lumpectomy and radiotherapy in the treatment of DCIS reduces the cumulative five-year incidence of a subsequent invasive tumor by 38%. I think that eating sensibly is a good idea for a lot of reasons, but treating or curing cancer is not one of them. Healthy eating does not cure cancer. There are no randomized double-blind controlled clinical trials supporting this. I have reviewed available literature on the raw diet and although it looks like a very healthy low fat way of eating, all beneficial claims come from testimonials, not scientific trials. Exercise may possibly reduce the risk of cancer, specifically colon cancer. Exercise will not treat or cure any forms of cancer that you have already. You should eat a sensible diet and exercise. Everyone should. But it is not a replacement for tamoxifen. With regard to your wanting to use natural progesterone cream when you have ductal carcinoma - would you check with your doctor and reply to this thread with exactly what his response was? I would like to read what he said. Thank you. Best wishes, -A

Posts.Content: quote: "Data from these studies after five and 10 years showed that women had the same survival rates whether they had mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery plus radiation. Now these two large studies have ended, and the final 20-year results confirm the earlier findings. They show that lumpectomy plus radiation is as effective as mastectomy for women with early-stage cancers that are under four centimeters." please read the full article: "Lumpectomy Plus Radiation as Effective as Mastectomy" http://www.breastcancer.org/research_surgery_101702.html ******************************* data from a large randomized controlled study is likely to be far more reliable than any testimonial evidence you get by asking friends or strangers on a message board what their results were. cancer can recur with either procedure, but the chance of recurrence, according to the studies, is the same. your chance of non-cancer complications is also something to consider. quote: "Chronic arm edema is a common finding after mastectomy and its pathophysiology is unclear." http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=11277318&dopt=Abstract (edema means swelling and i have seen lots of ladies with not only swollen arms that never get better, but weakness can also be a problem in the arm after mastectomy. usually this is after a radical mastectomy which means they go after lymph nodes and may damage nerves and muscles under the arm and breast.) your family history may help you decide. if there is a strong family history of non-ductal breast cancer in your mom, aunts and/or sisters, you might also be at risk for non-ductal regular breast cancer, and perhaps a mastectomy might be worthwhile. these are just some random thoughts of mine. read as much as you can, talk to your oncologist, and that way you can make the best decision for you. :-) Good luck, -A

Posts.Content: PET = for cancer specifically. cancer cells require a lot of sugar to reproduce as fast as they do. the injection you got prior to the pet scan is a radioactive sugar. the cancer cells suck up more sugar than the non-cancerous cells. so the cancerous areas of the body become more radioactive, and radioactivity is what the pet scan is taking pictures of. PET is probably the best way to find cancer which is why it is almost always part of a staging work up. pet scans look somewhat fuzzy and are sometimes hard to interpret unless a CT scan was done at the same time to compare the pet scan to. MRI / CT scans : similar pictures. CT scans are faster but involve ionizing radiation which is bad. MRI is slower but uses magnetism which is harmless. CT gives slightly better images of bone, MRI slightly better for soft tissues, but the difference is minimal. They are both excellent images and are not fuzzy looking. Trying to guess what to do next on your own, because you have concerns over your oncologist, is understandable. However, you do not have the years of medical basic science or clinical experience to make decisions that are anything but a guess, and experienced people on the internet have not examined you or your records or taken a detailed history so they also are not doing anything more than guessing. I know I say this a lot on this web site, but that is because it is very important. You have met your deductible so it is not a cost problem. And you are talking about something that could potentially affect whether you live only another couple of years vs many decades. Why not get a second opinion from someplace that is known for being outstanding in the cancer field? here they are. if someplace is close-by, go there. if it means a plane ride to any of them, might as well take a plane ride to #1 or #2. Posts.Content: usually, after lumpectomy, radiation to the breast and armpit are done. this will kill rogue cancer cells in the local area. usually, (and especially when lymph nodes are positive), chemotherapy is also done to kill any possible rogue cancer cells that escaped to your body. radiation and chemotherapy may or may not kill 100% of the cancer cells. usually when lymph nodes are negative and the tumor is less than 4 cm in size, just a lumpectomy is needed. usually when lymph node(s) are positive, a modified radical mastectomy is preferred. this is because if the cancer cells were able to get from the tumor to the lymph nodes, they had to go through the breast lymphatics to get there, and some "in-transit" cancer cells may still be in the breast. radiation and chemo may kill them, but surgical removal is more of a sure bet which is why modified radical mastectomy is usually preferred. it might be worth talking to the surgeon and asking him. there might be factors i am not aware of. in any case, your wounds need to fully heal before chemo and radiation begin. open wounds that are given radiation or chemotherapy won't close, the wound stays open and gets infected. statistics for survival of breast cancer are good and getting better every day with newer and better treatments. for a small, low grade cancer that has only spread to a few nodes, 10 year survival on the order of 75% or better. here are some statistics: http://www.cancerhelp.org.uk/help/default.asp?page=3317#large other opinions and suggestions welcome!

Posts.Content: X-Ray Place ------------------------- if the results are cancer, they do not want to be responsible to find a doctor to treat it. that is why they refuse to do a mammogram without a doctor's order. a doctor's order means that doctor will be responsible for you if it is cancer. even if you had insurance, the x-ray place will not do a mammogram without a doctor's order. Primary Care Doctor ------------------------- won't see you or order a mammogram because if it is cancer, there are no surgeons for them to refer you to for mastectomy because you have insurance. Surgeons ---------------- won't see you because if it is cancer, operating rooms won't schedule you unless you have insurance. commentary: Yes, I know this is all tragic and terrible and horrible and so forth. But put yourself in each of those positions above - lets say you are a surgeon with a generous heart and you do a biopsy in your office for free and it turns out to be cancer, then what? just exactly where are you going to do the mastectomy? you need an operating room with nurses and an anesthesiologist and maybe some sterile surgical tools. if you do not operate and the patient worsens, you will be sued for malpractice. then the patient will be able to afford insurance :) it is not the surgeons fault or the primary care doctors fault or even the radiologists fault. it is the fault of our system. it is not the fault of our doctors that we do not have universal health care. don't blame the doctors. write to your congressman! remember back a decade when clinton's universal health care bill was shot down by the republicans. i have not seen the republicans putting together any universal health care bills. get out and vote. if congress changes hands and the presidency changes hands maybe universal health care can become a reality and future young women will not have to go through this stress if they find a lump.
